I started to think if this is the only solution to bring flexibility to Livy docker image. I think it is a common problem for all the docker based applications, user requires to change parameters time to time even for docker based application. What is the common practice for such usage?

For example, Spark has a k8s support which requires a docker image, this Spark docker image doesn't have any configurations preset. When user runs Spark on k8s, user could configure the different properties to let Spark to honor. This seems a like similar scenario, I'm wondering why do have to use env variables for docker image?

Hello -- there are a number of solutions for configuring a docker image!  I took a very quick look at some of the most top docker images:

* by environment variable (like mysql),
* by mounting a config file (like nginx and httpd -- which also require mounting content to be useful!),
* by building a new docker image containing your customized config file and/or content (almost all of them, but not the flexibility we're looking for),
* by providing the config on the command line when you run the image (redis, memcached have examples).

The list isn't exclusive -- the image author can pick and choose one or more.  I'm intrigued by nginx, which optionally provides an "envsubst" approach to its config.

Another solution would be to permit substitution for environment variables in the Livy config parser directly, something HOCON-ish: https://github.com/lightbend/config/blob/master/HOCON.md#goals--background  For the community, it might be a plus to use an existing config library instead of maintaining it's own!

To be honest, by environment variable is by far the simplest for most of our deployments!  We use a variety of techniques with different products in dev and prod: one image per machine, or docker-compose, or (in some but not all cases) k8s.  Our devops discourage us from mounting volumes, although IIRC this is simpler if everything is deployed via k8s.

I'm not entirely sure about the rationale for the whitelist -- the system administrator or devops that has control over the whitelist is the same person that has control over setting environment variables for the image!

> Another solution would be to permit substitution for environment variables in the Livy config parser directly

Sorry -- on reflection, this is what @aromanenko-dev has done in this PR!

```
sudo -E apt-get ...
```
failed on one of the travis instances. Closing this PR and opening it again to rebuild.

Sorry I'm not familiar with k8s. I just saw Spark could support it.

My concern, a) I don't want all the configurations to support env variables, just several picked configurations. b) I don't want the name to be simply defined as upper case and hyphen, a proper name should be defined.

The existing logic is setting "rpc.server.address" to the host name where the RSC driver process is running. In a yarn cluster (for example), this driver process can be running in any node. So it's pointless for a user to configure that setting and the existing logic is good enough.

Unfortunately, for our use case, the solution with a limited set of "hardcoded" env variables, that can be used for configuration, won't work well. In this case, it would be easier and more generic to have default livy.conf template in the docker image which contains configuration options in the way like `livy.spark.master=$LIVY_SPARK_MASTER` and then can be substituted by env vars values with a help of `envsubst` on docker startup.
This PR, I think, should be closed then.
cc @jerryshao

IMHO, I think that this severely breaks Zeppelin,
My organisation has just upgraded to livy 0.5 and now the output of every line of scala code is being echoed to the browser.

for example this %livy code:
```scala
val x = 1
val y = 2
println(s"x + y = ${x + y}")
```
produces this output:
```
x: Int = 1
y: Int = 2
x + y = 3
```

The end result required to get a clean output is a cumbersome set of editing to create multiple paragraphs that set up output for display in subsequent paragraphs that can only contain println statements and hiding of the output of the "setup" paragraphs. Also, refreshing the display requires running both the "setup" and the "output" paragraphs. Previously, the "setup output" and "display output" logic could be combined in one paragraph. i.e. there was no need to create nor run separate paragraphs to get a clean output.
